articles.title: üéâ ¬†V8 is Faster and Safer Than Ever
articles.description: The V8 team wants to end the year on a high and they‚Äôve certainly pulled it off performance-wise. This post covers the highlights for the V8 engine in 2023, including the new Maglev mid-tier JIT compiler, the faster HTML parser, and support for several new JS features.
articles.author: Victor Gomes (V8)

articles.title: Announcing SvelteKit 2
articles.description: SvelteKit's first official release was a year ago, and despite its relative youth, the framework has been quickly embraced by the community. This 2.0 release is an incremental one, adding support for Vite 5, and laying the groundwork for Svelte 5 which is due for release in 2024.
articles.author: Svelte

articles.title: date-fns v3 Released
articles.description: The hugely popular suite of 200+ functions for working with dates in JavaScript has been rewritten in TypeScript, reintroduces String date arguments, has ESM support on Node, and all functions now export via named exports. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Sasha Koss

articles.title: v0: Vercel's AI-Powered React Component Creator
articles.description: The AI-powered v0 looked fascinating on its release, but has been stuck behind a waitlist till now. Vercel has dropped that list, opening it to all users. Even Larry David would admit it's pretty, pretty good.
articles.author: Vercel Labs

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†TypeScript Origins: The Documentary
articles.description: Videos don't tend to do well in JavaScript Weekly, but this was the most popular one, so I wanted to feature it again! I truly enjoyed watching all of this; it's so well made. It digs into the motivations and process behind TypeScript's creation and release, and could easily replace Die Hard in your Christmas rotation. Maybe.
articles.author: OfferZen

articles.title: Deep Cloning Objects in JavaScript, The Modern Way
articles.description: I'm as surprised as you, but this was the top-clicked link in 2023. If you‚Äôve been leaning on something like Lodash for deep cloning, we ‚Äúfinally now have the built-in structuredClone function to make deep cloning objects in JavaScript a breeze.‚Äù
articles.author: Steve Sewell

articles.title: Web Components Will Outlive Your JavaScript Framework
articles.description: Web Components have been having 'quite a moment' this year and this looks set to continue in 2024. This was a spicy opinion piece but the points raised provoked a lot of discussion and remain highly relevant in the JS zeitgeist.
articles.author: Jake Lazaroff

articles.title: You‚Äôve Got Options for Removing Event Listeners
articles.description: A review of some of the most common approaches available to remove event listeners in JavaScript.
articles.author: Alex MacArthur

articles.title: Things You Forgot (or Never Knew) Because of React
articles.description: The item that was popular in both this newsletter and our React newsletter and easily one of the 'classics' of the year.
articles.author: Josh Collinsworth

articles.title: Writing JavaScript Without a Build System
articles.description: Using a variety of build tools for things like bundling and transpiling is reasonably standard in modern JavaScript development, but what if you want to keep things simple? For simple things, it‚Äôs not necessary, says Julia. This led to a lot of discussion on Hacker News.
articles.author: Julia Evans

articles.title: UnsuckJS: Comparing Lightweight JavaScript Options
articles.description: A list of frontend JS libraries in a table on a single, fast page. It remains a handy way to see the relative popularity, file size, and latest versions of libraries as diverse as Preact, Bau, htmx, Hyperapp, and Mithril.
articles.author: Adam Hill

articles.title: React Libraries for 2023
articles.description: The React ecosystem is so large that there's often a problem of being spoiled for choice, so opinionated guides to different solutions tend to do well, like this annual list from Robin.
articles.author: Robin Wieruch

articles.title: A Huge Year for Playwright
articles.description: The popular Web testing and automation framework took some serious steps forward in 2023, particularly with v1.32.0 (linked above) offering a ‚ÄòUI mode‚Äô that lets you explore, run and debug tests in a UI environment, complete with built-in watch mode. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è This video provides a good introduction.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: You Don't (May Not) Need Lodash or Underscore
articles.description: Inspired by the popular You Might Not Need jQuery, this extensive document provides pure JS alternatives to almost 100 different functions as you‚Äôd find in popular utility libraries like Lodash.
articles.author: You Don't Need

articles.title: Driver.js: Tours, Highlights, Contextual Help, and More
articles.description: A no-dependency library for putting together on-page tours and contextual help. The project is a few years old but was rewritten in TypeScript in 2023, gained numerous enhancements, and got a fresh lick of paint.
articles.author: Kamran Ahmed

articles.title: Transformers.js: Running ML Models in Your Browser
articles.description: Transformers are a type of machine learning model often used in language or visual processing and while running these in the browser remains in its infancy, Transformers.js opens up some ML models to you with some impressive demos here.
articles.author: Xenova

articles.title: DeviceScript: Microsoft's Even-Tinier TypeScript
articles.description: DeviceScript brings the TypeScript experience to low-resource microcontroller devices. It‚Äôs compiled to a custom VM bytecode that can run in such constrained environments (a la Go‚Äôs TinyGo.) It‚Äôs aimed at VS Code users but there‚Äôs a CLI option.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.description: RIP Vue 2.x: If you're using Vue 2, be prepared: Vue 2 goes 'End of Life' (EOL) on December 31st, 2023.
We've revisited Robin Wieruch's 10 Web Development Trends in 2023 from January 2023 ‚Äì he was on the money with all of them.
Linus Schlumberger took a look back at all the main new JS and TS features of the past three years.
Conversely, The New Stack took to looking at what's next for JavaScript.

articles.title: Getting Started with Web Performance
articles.description: A solid look at how to up your web performance game, with strategies, tools and tips to help you make notable improvements. Lots of additional resources shared here too to help you push things further. Maybe a nice end of year project, making things speedier as we head into the new year?
articles.author: Alistair Shepherd

articles.title: Firefox 121 Released: New Features, Updates & Fixes
articles.description: A big release of Firefox just before the holidays (it shipped yesterday), featuring support for the :has() selector, <iframe> lazy loading, updated text-wrap property support, and more. Full developer-focused notes here.
articles.author: Mozilla

articles.title: Baseline in 2023
articles.description: Baseline is now added to the invaluable Can I Use. Rachel explains how the new integration works here, and highlights what features became part of the Baseline in 2023.
articles.author: Rachel Andrew

articles.title: Figma and Adobe Abandon Proposed Merger
articles.description: 15 months after announcing the deal, the companies no longer see a path toward regulatory approval. Figma will get a meaty billion dollar check from Adobe.
articles.author: Dylan Field (Figma)

articles.title: CSS animation-composition
articles.description: How to use the CSS animation-composition property for advanced control over how values are applied during keyframe animations.
articles.author: Tyler Gaw

articles.title: CSS Scroll Snapping Aligned with Global Page Layout: A Full-Width Slider Case Study
articles.description: Have you run into a situation where you need the padding of one element to align with the padding of another element? This article demonstrates the issue with a full-width slider component that breaks out of the main page container, sharing a couple of techniques to keep it visually aligned with other elements on the page.
articles.author: Brecht De Ruyte

articles.title: The Shrinkwrap Problem: Possible Future Solutions
articles.description: How anchor positioning can help tackle a CSS problem: shrinking containers to fit content when it automatically wraps.
articles.author: Roman Komarov

articles.title: Using Date-Based CSS to Make Old Web Pages Look Old
articles.description: Explores a way to access the published date metadata of a page in order to change the CSS based on its age.
articles.author: Terence Eden

articles.title: Three Modern CSS Properties Your Site Must Have
articles.description: A look at three ‚Äúlesser-known CSS secrets‚Äù that can go some way to help fix some UI problems on your website.
articles.author: Mojtaba Seyedi

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Igalia Chats: 2023 Year in Review
articles.description: Brian Kardell and Eric Meyer chat with Chrome DevRel Bramus Van Damme, reviewing the year of change in the Web Platform in an hour long discussion.
articles.author: Igalia podcast

articles.title: Locking Scroll with :has()
articles.description: A neat, handy little trick that uses :has() to prevent accidental page scrolling when modals are open.
articles.author: Robb Owen

articles.title: Announcing SvelteKit 2
articles.description: SvelteKit (the official toolkit for building Svelte webapps) is now one year old, and despite its relative youth, the framework has been quickly embraced by the community. This release is a relatively incremental one, adding support for Vite 5, and laying the groundwork for Svelte 5.
articles.author: Svelte

articles.title: pagefind-search Web Component
articles.description: This implements PageFind search in an Eleventy app using Eleventy island support (via the is-land component).
articles.author: Zach Leatherman

articles.title: Open Source Software: Open Source Alternatives to Popular¬†Projects
articles.description: Currently includes 500+ projects that can be searched via keyword or via category filters (analytics, APIs, monitoring, terminal, authentication, etc).
articles.author: john rush

articles.title: NinjaBootstrap: A Collection of SCSS Utilities to Extend Bootstrap¬†5
articles.description: Includes utilities for spacing, positioning, sizing, borders, and color theming, allowing you to have a little more control over Bootstrap‚Äôs default classes.
articles.author: Live Canvas

articles.title: SVG.io: Generate Custom SVG Images from a Text Prompt
articles.description: Simpler prompts will have better results and it‚Äôs free to use with no limitations (for now!). The generated SVG is monochrome but could be customized in your SVG editor of choice. I had mixed success, but it's an interesting idea.
articles.author: Digital Pixel
